When leaving for work one morning (thirty years ago), I found my car door open and my workout bag missing. I found the bag and some of the contents scattered along the next street.  Later in the day I heard a news story about a bicycle-car collision that occurred at 3:00 a.m. in a nearby intersection.  My overactive imagination hypothesized that peddling like crazy with stolen merchandise might have been a factor, so I followed up with APD.  The officer initially dismissed my theory, explaining the kid had no criminal history and possessed no stolen items.  He  eventually asked for a description of the stolen items.  Turns out that the kid's "bicycle" gloves were the same brand and color as my weightlifting gloves.  That made the officer a believer, but the amount missing didn't justify criminal charges.  The kid's injuries weren't serious, so I had to be satisfied with instant karma.

This proposal is unprecedented. No such regulations exist ANYWHERE in the USA. In fact, the proposal was put forth by the Wild Sheep Foundation, which cooperated with USDA and ADF&G in 2012 to make a lot of recommendations for the management of wild-to-domestic goat/sheep interactions.  Notice that the overwhelming portion of this document focuses on grazing on public lands: A practice that (to my knowledge) does not exist here AT ALL. This tells me that the risk of such transmissions is actually very unlikely.  How often do Alaskan farmers notice a wild ram/billie checking out their fenced ewes/nannies?  So the Wild Sheep Foundation is focusing on the least of the management strategies. And this is a lightly masked effort they're making to establish a legal precedent that can be carried to other states.  It's a BIG violation of private land use and everyone should be pissed. After serving for the past 6 months on the committee empowered to investigate this issue and write the proposed charter revisions and ballot question, and interviewing managers and mayors and looking at numerous governance histories of communities all over the USA, we came to the conclusion that Maui County would be better served with a professional manager with administrative training and skills, who is separated from the political process and subject to accountability. 

There would, for the first time, be annual evaluations of the effectiveness of the County Administration as a whole, and each Department and Director. This is closer to the way successful businesses, the military and over 60% of US municipalities function.

The Maui County Council will meet on Monday, June 27th under the Policy and Intergovernmental Affairs Committee to discuss whether the voters of Maui will have the opportunity to decide this issue, or whether the Council Members will deny the voters this choice.

The standard for placement for adjudicated patients is very basic: "the least restrictive appropriate placement available."  The State Hospital is the MOST restrictive placement available.  The Hospital cost is (info from the DHS) $280,000/bed per year.  Note that's "per bed", not per patient.  Fewer patients does not equal a corresponding decrease in cost.  Community based care is more appropriate and more effective in transitioning patients back into the Community.  Additionally, its estimated cost is $70,000/patient per year; with 50% federal reimbursement from the federal government. (no reimbursement for the Hospital).  

The legislature chose to build the "hospital"...it looks like a prison because it was designed for conversion to one if needed.  That decision was a disservice to Oregon's mentally ill population and Oregon taxpayers.
